text: hello everyone
my name is sarah bhutyani and i'm a
senior analytics specialist solutions
architect
at ews today we will learn about athena
federated queries
and see a demo of configuring and
running federated queries
so what is a federated query a federated
query is simply a query that you can
write in sql
and that query can scan data from
different data sources
that could be relational or or
non-relational or they could be your
object data stores
or even they could be custom data
sources you can run query across
on-premises
or cloud data sources and it can also be
used for ad-hoc queries or building
multiple complex pipelines
so what happens when you submit your
federated query when you submit your
federated query to athena
athena first has to connect to your
target data source
we refer that data source as federated
data source
to connect to the federated data source
athena uses a new construct called
federated data source connector
these connectors are basically connected
codes which run in your account as
lambda functions
when you submit a federated query to
athena it will invoke multiple lambda
functions in order to optimize your
performance and filter the results in
the most performant manner possible
you can think of a connector as an
extension of athena's query engine
when a query runs on a federated data
source athena will find out the lambda
invocations reading metadata and data in
parallel
and the number of these parallel
invocations depend on the lambda
concurrency limits in your account
you can combine sql statement from
multiple catalogs and span multiple data
sources with a single query
when a query submitted against the data
source athena invokes the corresponding
connector
to identify parts of the tables that
needs to be read
manages parallelism and pushes down
filter predicates to improve performance
so now the question is is predicted
query simple to use and we can
confidently respond to that as
yes it is extremely simple to use there
are only three simple steps to follow
first is discover you need to select the
data source connector to use from athena
console or serverless application
repository
second step is selection where you fill
out the connector parameters and deploy
and finally query where you start
running your federated queries from
athena console or using the api.cli
with that let's get into the demo mode
